learning_outcomes.description: Identify a research topic within the field of English Literature.
Plan and carry out research within the field of English Literature.
Access, evaluate and critique primary and secondary sources.
Develop an argument critically and clearly.

assessments.due_date:
16/10/2026 1:00 pm

Submit two bound copies of your thesis and an electronic version also needs to be uploaded via Turnitin.
assessments.task_description:
Students work in conjunction with a Supervisor to research and present a 15,000-word dissertation.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Two bound copies of your thesis are to be submitted to the School of Communication and Arts Office, 6th Floor, Michie Building. An electronic version also needs to be uploaded via Turnitin. For further submission information, please refer to the School of Communication and Arts honours webpage.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
30/10/2026

Students will receive an invitation from the School of Communication & Arts with the time and location information for their oral defence in the early weeks of Semester 2, 2026.
assessments.task_description:
Students will meet with their supervisor and two thesis examiners and conduct an oral defence of their thesis. The format of the defence will include a brief thesis overview (3mins) and Question and Answer session (10mins) in response to unseen questions. 

The oral defence will be marked on a pass/fail basis and be assessed against the following criteria:

  • Demonstrated ability to articulate the rationale underpinning the choice of central research question/s, the identification of a key gap in knowledge that the thesis addresses, and the devising of the central hypothesis.
  • Demonstrated ability to justify the thesis structure.
  • Demonstrated ability to explain and justify the methodology/ies used.
  • Demonstrated mastery of knowledge, analysis and findings presented in the thesis.
  • Ability to satisfactorily respond to spontaneous and pertinent questions in the oral defence.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
